lenders.name: Sandra Kay Bitner
lenders.loan_because: I made a pact with God and the Grandfathers on Christmas Day 1997; that if they would teach me the internet I would donate 50% to feed the homeless and the poor.
lenders.occupational_info:
Disaster relief efforts proved to be very rewarding during the aftermath of Hurricanes Ivan through Rita. Not only were people hungry but they were distressed and traumatized. No one can express or explain in words the gratitude that comes from one smile as a plate of food is passed. I find saying the blessing while I am cooking does not offend anyone and as a Cherokee and daughter of an apothecary it gives me great pleasure. I remember serving 29,850 meals in 5 days alongside other Red Cross volunteers.

My efforts in disaster relief proved to be very rewarding. After all, it is usually the poor and poverty stricken that are the neglected in such situations. The rich seem to know who and how to contact someone and get their hands on the money even if they are not entitled to it.

What I have learned in my 57 years is how to deal with the aftermath of eco-disasters. When it is time to pinch pennies, the greedy seem to  grab millions and the glutenous take food they do not need or want...just because they can.

My economic policy is to keep $28.50 US in my wallet. This is my petty cash fund so to speak. Each week I replenish this if funds are 
available. I never seem to want for a meal from a dollar menu that way. No matter what country I am in doing my missionary work, this amount 
in any currency seems to keep my stomach warm and my thoughts absent of greed and gluteny.

When I learned that KIVA did the same thing for people around the world yet in $25.00 increments, I knew this would be an avenue of 
financial intervention where I could do work for GOD.

lenders.name: Delaney & Mitchell

lenders.occupational_info: We are students in the 5th (Mitch) and 8th (Delaney) grades.
